question: Question_B_04_(a)
statement:
Let \emph{A} be the $3 \times 3$ matrix given by

\begin{align*}\begin{bmatrix}
-7 & 0 & 1 \\
0 & 3 & 0 \\
-2 & 0 &-4
\end{bmatrix}\end{align*}

It is known that $\lambda_{1} = 3$ is an eigenvalue of \emph{A}.

Find an eigenvector associated with the eigenvalue $\lambda_{1} = 3$.
sols:
Proceeding as usual, we look for non-zero solutions to

\begin{align*}0 = (A-3I)v = \begin{bmatrix}
-10 & 0 & 1 \\ 0 & 0 & 0 \\ -2 & 0 & -7
\end{bmatrix}v\end{align*}

The free variable is \emph{v\textsubscript{2}}, while there is a system
of two equations and two unknowns for \emph{v\textsubscript{1}} and
\emph{v\textsubscript{3}}. The (simplest and only) solution to this
smaller system is \emph{v\textsubscript{1} = 0 = v\textsubscript{3}}.
Hence, any vector of the form

\begin{align*}v = \begin{bmatrix} 0 \\ a \\ 0 \end{bmatrix}\end{align*}

with $a \not= 0$ is an eigenvector of \emph{A} with eigenvalue 3.
